answers.explanation:
Rosiglitazone (A), trastuzumab (B), fingolimod (C), paclitaxel (D) and Siponimod (F) are all medications that have been linked with the development of cystoid macular edema (CME).

​Fingolimod and Siponimod are both selective sphingosine-1-phosphate receptor modulators used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis.

​Nitrofurantoin has not been linked with the development of CME, but has been associated with crystalline retinopathy.

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
![](/content/media/neuro-ophthalmology-15-1.webp)

An OCT macula was performed in both eyes, which was normal in the right eye. The OCT macula of the left eye is shown above. Which layer of the retina is the yellow arrow pointing to?

answers.explanation: The inner nuclear layer consists of cell bodies of horizontal cells, bipolar cells, amacrine cells, and Muller cells. It can be identified on OCT as the first inner dark gray band.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text:
![](/content/media/neuro-ophthalmology-15-2.webp)

What is the most notable abnormality in the OCT macula above?

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/neuro-ophthalmology-15-2.webp)

There are multiple micro-cystoid changes in the inner nuclear layer. Of note, the outer plexiform layer appears normal.

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text:
![](/content/media/neuro-ophthalmology-15-3.webp)

An OCT RNFL (shown above) was performed demonstrating optic atrophy OU secondary to previous episodes of optic neuritis. On further history, the patient does not endorse any change in vision. Based on this information, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.answerText: C. Microcysts in the INL from optic atrophy
answers.explanation:
Microcystoid changes in the inner nuclear layer have been reported in patients with optic atrophy due to a combination of trans-synaptic degeneration of the inner nuclear layer and vitreous traction on the retinal surface. These changes have been identified in patients with multiple sclerosis, Leber’s Hereditary Optic Neuropathy, Dominant Optic Atrophy, and optic glioma and do not represent drug-induced macular edema.

It is important for clinicians to recognize and differentiate these degenerative INL changes from cystoid macular edema of another etiology as it can impact the treatment regimen of patients with MS.

title: Case 15
description: 49M presenting for evaluation of possible macular edema
patientPresentation: A 49-year-old male was referred to ophthalmology for evaluation of possible macular edema. He has a history of secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (MS) diagnosed in 1993 and has a remote history of optic neuritis in both eyes. His neurologist is planning on starting a new medication for MS and macular edema is considered a contraindication. A referral is sent to ophthalmology to rule out macular edema.
